case_vignette: A 32-year-old white woman who has never smoked presents with pruritic, tender, erythematous, violaceous patches with eczema-like blisters on her upper, lateral thighs. In 2012, she began traveling annually from Pennsylvania to South Carolina, from January through April, where she works with and rides horses daily from morning to evening. Her symptoms began in her first year in South Carolina and appear consistently from January through March. Her lesions appear initially in mid-January as a red dot and progress by mid-February. They resolve spontaneously in March. The patient has no history of allergies, eczema, or other skin conditions. She has no family history of allergies or eczema. Her physical examination reveals a normal skin examination, except for the lesions on her thighs. The patient has a history of sunburns, but no history of sun protection. The patient has a history of working outdoors in the sun for extended periods of time. The patient has a history of working with horses, which involves exposure to horse dander and other allergens. The patient has a history of riding horses, which involves exposure to horse dander and other allergens. The patient has a history of working outdoors in the sun for extended periods of time. Final Diagnosis: Seasonal allergic contact dermatitis
